human_readable_transcript:
Before continuing with the previous CHECKLIST, please triage if the patient mentions anything that indicates that the patient has systolic blood pressure above 160 OR a diastolic blood pressure above 100. Today is December 19, 2023 and time is 09:34 PM. Patient is 81 years old. Patient's gender is male. Patient is actively suffering with the following conditions: Stage II CKD, Type II Diabetes, HTN. Patient is currently taking the following medications: Losartan 25 mg oral tablet, Lantus 100 iu/ mL prefilled pen, Aspart 100 IU/mL prefilled pen. Use the following questions to triage the high_bp kickout. Be concise and ONLY acknowledge or respond to the patient's response by saying nothing or 'Okay'. DO NOT say you are sorry or that you see or that you understand.
Please follow the order of the follow up questions exactly as listed below. DO NOT skip any question:
1. Confirm again with the patient you heard them correctly that the patient's blood pressure is high. If the patient answers negatively, skip the rest of the questions.
2. If the patient has not told you their blood pressure reading, what is the patient's blood pressure reading
3. When was the patient's blood pressure reading taken
4. If the patient's blood pressure reading was not taken now or in the past 24 hours, can the patient recheck their blood pressure right now
5. If the patient can recheck their blood pressure right now, what is the patient's current blood pressure reading
6. Does the patient currently have dizziness or lightheadedness or profuse sweating
7. Does the patient currently have chest pain
8. Does the patient currently have a headache
9. Does the patient have any more information they want to share about this issue?

After all the follow up questions are done, please continue with the CHECKLIST where you left off.
</KICKOUT_CHECKLIST><</SYS>>
Patient: Hello? 

 Nurse: Hi, this is Rachel calling from O'Connor Hospital on a recorded line. Is this Timothy Peck? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Thanks for taking my call. Just so you know, I'm your AI Chronic Care Manager. Thousands of real doctors and nurses helped train me to care for patients like you. I've also studied hundreds of medical certification exams and your care team provided me with notes to prepare for this call. -- To protect your privacy, can you please share your date of birth before we begin? 

 Patient: Sure. My birthday is April three nineteen forty two. 

 Nurse: Thank you for confirming that, Mr. Peck. I'm calling on behalf of your primary care doctor, Doctor Maria Rodriguez, to check in on you. How have you been doing recently? 

 Patient: I've been doing okay. 

 Nurse: I'm glad to hear that you're doing okay. Before we delve into some health topics, I'd like to get to know you a bit better. Is there anything you're looking forward to doing this week? 

 Patient: It's Patient: Not much really. Just looking forward to spending time with family. 

 Nurse: That sounds lovely, spending time with family is always special. Who in your family will you be spending time with? 

 Patient: Just my kids. 

 Nurse: That's wonderful. Spending time with children can be such a joy. What activities do you usually enjoy doing together? 

 Patient: We'll be going 

 Nurse: That sounds like a great plan. I hope you have a wonderful time. 

 Patient: around town trying out a new restaurant. 

 Nurse: That sounds like a fun outing. Trying new restaurants can be an exciting adventure. Do you have a type of cuisine you're particularly fond of? 

 Patient: We like to try each and everything. So 

 Nurse: That's a great approach, keeping an open mind to different cuisines. It can make for some interesting meals. Before we move on to discuss your health, is there anything you've been feeling concerned about lately? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: Okay then, if you have any questions or concerns at any point during our conversation, feel free to bring them up. Would it be alright if we go over a few topics related to your health now? 

 Patient: Yeah. Go on. 

 Nurse: Thank you, Mr. Peck. Since you have Type II Diabetes, it's important to monitor your blood sugar levels regularly. Have you been checking your blood sugar daily? 

 Patient: Yeah. 

 Nurse: That's good to hear. Could you share what your last blood sugar reading at home was? 

 Patient: I believe it was one forty eight 

 Nurse: Okay. When did you take this blood sugar reading? 

 Patient: In the morning. Patient: When I first woke up. 

 Nurse: Thank you for sharing that. A fasting blood sugar level of 148 is a bit higher than the target range, which is usually under 130. Would you be open to discussing some strategies to help manage your blood sugar levels? 

 Patient: Well, I've read everything. I've been told I'm not really interested right now. 


 <<SYS>> <TASK>Amazing! You are aware of the lab values. If the user mentions a value outside plausible range, confirm whether it was the correct value.
Ask the patient question Was your blood sugar taken fasting, after a meal, or was it a random sample?
Based on their response, relevant lab values apply:
1. For answer 'Fasting' The normal range for glucose is 60 to 105 mg/dL. Inform the patient that the value they mentioned is greater than the normal range. Do not comment beyond that, do not refer to any medical condition or symptoms the patient may have. If they ask more questions, tell them that you'll make a note of the lab value for their doctor
2. For answer 'Random' The normal range for glucose is 60 to 140 mg/dL. Inform the patient that the value they mentioned is greater than the normal range. Do not comment beyond that, do not refer to any medical condition or symptoms the patient may have. If they ask more questions, tell them that you'll make a note of the lab value for their doctor
3. For answer 'After meal' The normal range for glucose is 60 to 180 mg/dL. Inform the patient that the value they mentioned is within the normal range. Do not comment beyond that, do not refer to any medical condition or symptoms the patient may have. If they ask more questions, tell them that you'll make a note of the lab value for their doctor

Don't specify unit unless patient asks for it.</TASK><</SYS>>


 Nurse: Got it -- Mr. Peck. It's important to keep track of these readings and share them with your healthcare team. Just to clarify, was this blood sugar reading taken fasting, after a meal, or was it a random sample? 

 Patient: It was taken before a meal. 

 Nurse: Thank you for clarifying. A fasting blood sugar level of 148 is a bit higher than the target range, which is usually under 130. I'll make a note of this for your doctor. Let's move on to your blood pressure. When did you last measure it? 

 Patient: Last night. 

 Nurse: Thank you for sharing that. Could you also tell me what the result was? 

 Patient: I believe it was one thirty out of eighty 

 Nurse:

responses.G15: Thank you for that information, Mr. Peck. A blood pressure reading of 130/80 is within the normal range, which is good. It's important to keep monitoring it regularly. Would you be open to discussing some strategies to help maintain your blood pressure levels?
responses.G15DPO: Thank you for confirming your blood pressure reading. The values you mentioned are within the acceptable range, which is good news. Do you have any questions about your recent lab results?
responses.gpt4: That's a good reading. A blood pressure of 130/80 is within the target range for most people. It's essential to keep monitoring it regularly. If you haven't taken it today, could you please do so and let me know the result?
